div.head: Description of Monument
div.p: White marble block (0.41 x 0.37 x depth not measurable). The upper left corner and all edges are chipped, and there is a crack across the lower right corner.

div.head: Description of Text .
div.p: Inscribed on the face, within a partly smoothed area

div.head: Letters
div.p: 0.02-0.03; theta and omicron smaller than the rest

div.head: Date
div.p: First century B.C. to first century A.D.(lettering)

div.head: Apparatus
div.p: It is not clear to which of the two masculine names Kastaios was attached, but there is some indication in Aphrodisian practice that it would probably be Athenagoras.

div.head: Translation
div.p: Aba, (daughter of) Atrapatos, and wife of Athenagoras, son of Menodotos, also called Kastaios. Farewell.

div.head: Commentary
div.p: The funerary formula accords with a comparatively early date (cf also Robert, loc. cit.); the names show interestingly various but non-Roman features.

Aba seems to be an indigenous name attested both elsewhere in Caria and also in Cilicia and Phrygia (see Zgusta, Kleinasiatischen Personennamen (Prague, 1984), especially section 1, Blümel, Die Inschriften der rhodischen Peraia (Bonn, 1991). Atrapates is Iranian. Athenagoras and Menodotos are Greek, and in fairly common use at Aphrodisias, (see name index), notably in a prominent family of the first and second centuries A.D. which inluded a Mithridates son of Athenagoras (see 12.410). Mithridates, like Atrapates, is Itranian, and both are clearly survivals from the Persian occupation of Asia Minor.

Kastaios is probably an indigenous personal name (so Buckler, Appendix V to Sardis 6.2), but has been seen by some as a demotic (Brandenstein in RE 6, s.v. Karische Sprache, 140f, 141); there is however no clear evidence for the use of demotics at Aphrodisias.

div.head: Text Constituted From
div.p: Reichel squeeze and notebook; transcription (Reynolds); publications.

div.head: History of Recording
div.p: Copied by Radet; by Reichel (R.I.36a); recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition.
